unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Find the Null
question_text: Which of the following is a null hypothesis for a chi-square test of homogeneity?

choices.text: $H_{0}$: Two categorical variables in a population are associated.
$H_{0}$: There is no difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.
$H_{0}$: The proportions given for a set of categorical data are what they are.
$H_{0}$: There is a difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.
$H_{0}$: There is no association between two categorical variables in a given population

solution:
Solution

The chi-square test for homogeneity looks to see if there are differences in distributions of a categorical variable across populations

The null hypothesis for this test assumes that there is no difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.

The alternative hypothesis for this test assumes that there is a difference in distributions of a categorical variable across populations.

Note that if only two populations are involved, then a test for a difference in population proportions could also be done.

So, Choice 'B' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because this is the alternative hypothesis for the chi-square test for independence.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because this is the null hypothesis for the chi-square test for goodness of fit.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because this is the alternative hypothesis for the chi-square test for homogeneity.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because this is the null hypothesis for the chi-square test for independence.
